I think you are asking how does light have energy without mass. The energy in E=mc^2 is often call the “rest mass energy,” but it is not the only kind of energy a thing can have. If you factor in kinetic energy, the equation becomes [math]E = \gamma mc^2[/math] where [math]\gamma = \frac{1}{\sqrt{1-v^2/c^2}}[/math] Which can, with some algebra, be written as [math]E^2 = m^2c^4 + p^2c^2[/math] where p is the movementum. Light doesn’t have mass, but it does carry momentum. and technically, the value of [math]\gamma[/math] would be infinite for light, so in the first equation I wrote, you have an infinite values times zero, which mathematicians will tell you, could be anything. In summary, E=mc^2 tells you that light can not exist at rest. [math]E = \gamma mc^2[/math] tells you light can only exist at lightspeed. And [math]E^2 = m^2c^4 + p^2c^2[/math] tells you that the energy that light carries is directly proportional to its momentum.
